pages.title: Purpose of the site registration request

components.name: fdtJAt
components.title: Html
components.content:
If you are carrying out mitigation work to preserve public health and safety, you must be able to demonstrate that there is a genuine public health and safety issue. Natural England will issue a Further Information Request in circumstances when you cannot demonstrate this satisfactorily.

Your evidence should comprise a written report or assessment from a suitably qualified person who has assessed health and safety risk to the public.

components.name: QDGVXO
components.title: What's the purpose of the work being carried out on the site?
components.hint: If more than one purpose applies, select the most relevant purpose for work you are going to be carrying out.

pages.title: Consent conditions or reserved matters

components.name: bzkOjc
components.title: Html
components.content:
We usually need all relevant wildlife and habitat conditions and reserved matters of the consent granted addressed before work starts. This helps us get the details and certainty we need.

If you cannot discharge the conditions or reserved matters related to the consent before development starts, or do not intend to tick 'No'

pages.title: What's the appointed person's name?

components.name: wgAPqx
components.title: Html
components.content:
By completing this form, you are confirming that you are authorised to act on behalf of the company or organisation.

If the a site registration request is granted by Natural England, the acting on behalf of organisation subsequently becomes the Joint Licensee.

what it means to be a Joint Licensee

components.name: QEyvVf
components.title: What's the appointed person's name?

pages.title: Registering a site on behalf of an organisation

components.name: leVwSH
components.title: Html
components.content:
By completing this section of the form, you are confirming that the named contact is authorised to act on behalf of the company or organisation.

The joint licensee should ensure they have appropriate evidence that this contact is authorised to act on behalf of the company or organisation.

Appropriate evidence of this would include:

  • Companies incorporated in the UK: Articles of Association
  • Limited Liability Partnerships (LLPs): a partnership agreement
  • Charities: a trust deed which lists the trustees
  • Government departments or LPA: scheme of delegation

You do not need to provide this evidence as part of the site registration, but it should be available if requested.

pages.title: Protected sites

components.name: fseDwO
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must tell us if the licensable activity you want to carry out is have the potential to impact an protected site.

Protected sites are areas of land or sea that are designated for the conservation of wildlife, habitats, or geological features.

Protected sites in England include:

  • Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSIs)
  • Special Areas of Conservation (SACs)
  • Special Protection Areas (SPAs)
  • Ramsar wetland sites

Use Defra Magic Maps to find out if your land is on a protected site,by:

  1. Visit the Defra Magic Maps website.
  2. In the search bar located in the left corner of the website, enter your postcode, grid reference, or coordinates.
  3. Click the search button.
  4. The map will zoom in on your location. Any protected sites in the area will be highlighted as coloured, hatched areas with labels. If nothing is displayed, it means your land is likely not on a protected site.
  5. Click on the 'i' identify tool in the toolbar at the top of the screen to find out the name of the protected site by clicking on the map with the appearing crosshair.

pages.title: Habitat Regulations Assessment (HRA)

components.name: IyPwfL
components.title: Html
components.content:
You must provide an Habitat Regulations Assessment (HRA) appropriate assessment which covers the licensable activities you intend to carry out.

If there is not an HRA already produced and available (for example, in support of a planning application), Natural England may require further information from you. If required, contact will be made following submission of this site registration request.

Where proposed impacts may concern a protected site, Natural England may have to consult with the Protected Sites team. If this is required, we will need to add 28 days to the 15 working day turnaround time, to allow time for the consultation.

components.name: PUYuPr
components.title: Upload your HRA
components.hint: Upload a copy  of your HRA  in Word, PDF or JPEG. The maximum file size for each file is 100MB

pages.title: Do the proposed works affect a roost of high conservation significance?

components.name: oaqNUL
components.title: Html
components.content:
This category includes maternity and hibernation sites of Annex II species, very large traditional maternity colonies of any species, hibernation sites used by significant numbers of bats of any species, Regionally and Nationally important roosts of any species, and sites meeting nationally and internationally designated site status.

It also includes sites that have potential to qualify as a designated site for bats, as per the Joint Nature Conservation Committee (JNCC) SSSI Guidelines: Chapter 16 Mammals (opens in a new tab).

components.name: aVYjkO
components.title: Do the proposed works affect a roost of high conservation significance?

pages.title: How will the works likely to affect the roosts of high conservation significance?

components.name: hMvarA
components.title: How will the works likely to affect the roosts of high conservation significance?

pages.title: What's the level of disturbance?

components.name: ZJBSAI
components.title: Html
components.content:
Natural England views the offences, defences and licensing options linked to the disturbance of bats jointly under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (WCA) and the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 (Habitats Regulations).

There are 4 levels of regulatory approach to the disturbance of birds.

Level 1: No offence is likely as only negligible disturbance is predicted

A threshold of no significant disturbance ‘above what normally occurs onsite’ (baseline levels) can be used to capture such instances. No notification to, or licence from, Natural England is required in such instances.

Level 2: A WCA disturbance offence is likely but only in relation to low-level disturbance impacts

Natural England’s expectation is that you rely on the ‘Incidental Result Defence’ derogation in Section 10(3)(c) of the WCA; ‘the act was the incidental result of a lawful operation and could not reasonably have to be avoided’.

You must notify Natural England in line with Section 10(5) that they intend to rely on the defence in or where a licence is being issued for other licensable impacts (for example, roost destruction) associated with the disturbance.

Natural England can issue a licence that will cover these WCA-low level disturbance impacts also to avoid the need for a separate notification to be submitted.

Level 3: A WCA disturbance offence is likely and there are higher levels of disturbance impact (for example, to population level)

The levels of impact are likely fall beneath the established-practice Habitats Regulations threshold (it is likely that this route would only be used in exceptional circumstances due to the very narrow range of cases that will fall under this level).

Natural England’s expectation is that a WCA licence should be obtained due to the higher levels of impact.

Level 4: Disturbance which would likely cause an offence under the Habitats Regulations and the WCA

This would be disturbance to the bats that are likely to impact the bats:

  • at population level
  • ability to survive, breed or hibernate, at the appropriate scale

Natural England’s expectation is that a licence should be requested to cover both the WCA and the Habitats Regulations for the disturbance offences.
